title: Ornamental knotted facade adorns Bogotá book pavilion
author: Niall Patrick Walsh
excerpt: In Colombia, the Bogotá International Book Fair has just concluded its 2025 edition. This year, Spain was the guest of honor, with the Spanish Pavilion constructing a pavilion with a unique macramé facade. The pavilion’s exhibition was titled ‘Drawn Memory,’ celebrating the significant...
text: anchor Image credit: Javier Agustín Rojas via Instagram In Colombia, the Bogotá International Book Fair has just concluded its 2025 edition. This year, Spain was the guest of honor, with the Spanish Pavilion constructing a pavilion with a unique macramé facade. The pavilion’s exhibition was titled ‘Drawn Memory,’ celebrating the significant role of comics in recovering and disseminating Spanish historical memory. The organizers also brought a delegation of 140 authors and a tribute to rural libraries as a symbol of cultural resistance. Outside, a 2370-square-foot macrame facade welcomed visitors at the entrance to the pavilion. A form of textile knotting dating back thousands of years, macramé is often employed as a technique for creating elaborate, ornamental forms, in this case casting a variety of geometric patterns across the facade and canopy. The project was authored by Lluís Alexandre Casanovas Blanco, Paula Chalkho Rozenblum, Enrique Espinosa Pérez, and Santiago Pradilla Hosie, alongside collaborators Irene Domínguez, Sofía Marciel, and Jaime de la Torre.

    In Colombia, the Bogotá International Book Fair has just concluded its 2025 edition. This year, Spain was the guest of honor, with the Spanish Pavilion constructing a pavilion with a unique macramé facade.

    The pavilion’s exhibition was titled ‘Drawn Memory,’ celebrating the significant role of comics in recovering and disseminating Spanish historical memory. The organizers also brought a delegation of 140 authors and a tribute to rural libraries as a symbol of cultural resistance.

    Outside, a 2370-square-foot macrame facade welcomed visitors at the entrance to the pavilion. A form of textile knotting dating back thousands of years, macramé is often employed as a technique for creating elaborate, ornamental forms, in this case casting a variety of geometric patterns across the facade and canopy.

    The project was authored by Lluís Alexandre Casanovas Blanco, Paula Chalkho Rozenblum, Enrique Espinosa Pérez, and Santiago Pradilla Hosie, alongside collaborators Irene Domínguez, Sofía Marciel, and Jaime de la Torre.
